They scale fine, but I think basic scaling leaves the icons looking a little bland. A larger icon allows for finer detail.

Agreed. I think eventually it would be a great idea to make a custom 48x48 set. Right now, I'm trying to get everything set up to launch v2.0.0 and want to focus on building up a strong core set of 24x24 icons.

The reason I made the `search` and `zoom` circles different is because the dimensions of the `zoom` circle need to be *even* in order to center the `+` and `-`. I thought that 16x16 circle looked a little too large for `search` because there there's nothing inside the circle. 15x15 seemed to work pretty well for search.

Can you think of any scenarios where the different sizes might cause problems?

I don't think there would be a specific, isolated scenario where it might cause problems, just that the inconsistency is a problem in itself.

I actually prefer the 16px circle for `search`, I like the added weight on the glass of the magnifying glass-it adds legibility I think, especially at a smaller 16px size.

Not a big deal but certainly an inconsistency imo.

I'll have to think about the icon font. I tend to discourage the use of icon fonts in general because I think SVGs are a much better alternative. Also, tools like Icomoon make it super easy to generate your own icon font from a set of SVGs. I would argue that using Icomoon is actually better because you can create a set with only the icons you need.

Here are some good articles comparing SVG to icon fonts:
  - [Inline SVG vs Icon Fonts [CAGEMATCH]](https://css-tricks.com/icon-fonts-vs-svg/)
  - [Seriously, Don’t Use Icon Fonts](https://cloudfour.com/thinks/seriously-dont-use-icon-fonts/)
  - [Ten reasons we switched from icon font to SVG](http://ianfeather.co.uk/ten-reasons-we-switched-from-an-icon-font-to-svg/)

I ve read those articles from your changelog, personally I think both svgs and iconfonts have optimal use-cases. Due to icomoon's restriction of stroke shaped svgs I guess I could fork your repo, expand shapes and have only the converted icons for icomoon usage (if you are ok with this ofc).

Also, I ll research and try to setup some categories to send you. I hope you find them usefull (may take some days, im a little busy right now)

Hey, i didnt have time to research more, hope the following are enough to get you started for whatever you end up with :)

---

Some categories not analyzed:

- Application / Action / Users
- Accessibility + Gestures
- Devices (Communication / Hardware / etc)
- Image (Contrast / Brightness / Crop / etc)
- Maps + Places + Transportation

Some analyzed:

- Navigation (menu, arrows, etc)
- Form Elements (checkboxes, radio, ...)
- Media Controls (Audio / Video / etc)
- File
	- Types (text, zip, image, video, ...)
	- Cloud (upload, download, ...)
	- Misc (dir-closed, dir-open, ...)
- Brand
	- Browsers (chrome, firefox, safari, ...)
	- Social (fb, twitter, pinterest, ...)
	- Misc (lastfm, github, steam, ...)
- Payment
	- Currencies (usd, euro, gbp, ...)
	- Ways (paypal, master,	bitcoin, ...)
- Charts (pie, bars, line, ...)
- WYSIWYG
	- Texts (H1-H6, paragraph, quote, pre, ...)
	- Align (left, center, right, justify)
	- Style (bold, italics, underline, strike-through, indent, outdent)
	- Lists (ul, ol)
	- Misc (link, image, ...)
	- From other categories (undo, redo, copy, cut, paste, ...)
- Platform (android, ios, windows, blackberry, ...)
- Games
	- Chess: 6 icons (king, queen, rook, bishop, knight, pawn)
	- Backgammon: 6 icons (dice 1-6)
	- Cards: 4 icons (spades, hearts, clubs, diamonds)
- Weather (rainy, stormy, sunny, cloudy, hot, cold, dry, wet, ...)

In v2.1.0, I started using [SVGO](https://github.com/svg/svgo) to optimize the SVGs, so the new icons now have `stroke` and other attributes applied to the elements of the SVG instead of the SVG tag itself. This new approach speeds up development time by quite a bit. I plan to make the older icons follow this same pattern for consistency.

Can you think of any reasons why applying attributes to the SVG tag (the old way) might be better than the contents of the SVG (the new way)? 

Also, thanks for catching the `#0f0f0f`! I'll fix that right now.

> Can you think of any reasons why applying attributes to the SVG tag (the old way) might be better than the contents of the SVG (the new way)?

I think there is no difference. I still can change stroke color by CSS: `svg * { stroke: currentColor; }` instead `svg { stroke: currentColor; }`.

But with attributes in `<svg>` tag icons have a little bit smaller size if they have more than one element.
For example updated icon `user` has 364 bytes. After moving attributes to `<svg>` it will have 274 bytes.

One of the guiding principles of Feather is that all icons use a 2px stroke with no fill. This creates consistency. Having a filled star would break this pattern and wouldn't fit in with the rest of the set. For that reason, I don't think it's a good idea to add it.

That being said, I realize that there are valid use cases for a filled star. The good news is that SVGs are very flexible and can be used in a variety of ways. It wouldn't be hard for anyone to add a `fill` to the star outline if they needed a solid star ⭐️

Here are my ideas on ways Feather could be used: ## Option 1: Copy & Paste If you only need one or two icons, copying and pasting the SVG code directly into your markup might be the best solution. This is by far the simplest way to use Feather. ## Option 2: Node For more advanced use cases, Feather could expose an `icons` object, making icon information easily accessible. Additionally, Feather could provide a `toSVG` method that accepts an icon name and an options object and returns a string of the ` ``` This option would be good for prototyping in the browser because it could utilize a CDN. ## Option 4: Spritesheet Feather could generate an SVG sprite by looping over every key in `feather.icons` object. To use the sprite, you could either paste the contents of `feather.svg` immediately below the opening `body` tag and use it like this: ```html ``` or just reference `feather.svg` like this: ```html ``` I know IE has some problems referencing external SVGs in this way so we would probably have to provide a polyfill of some kind. ## Final Thoughts I'd like to keep the main `feather` repo as barebones as possible and keep it platform agnostic. We can create helper repos like `react-feather` for platform specific use cases. I'd love to get feedback on these ideas. Let me know if you have any ideas about how to best deliver Feather. I want to design the best possible experience for Feather users before getting in the weeds with implementation details.

To automate converting strokes to paths, you can customize this script:

```bash
#!/bin/bash

echo $1
sed -i 's/stroke-width="2"/stroke-width="1"/g' $1
inkscape $1 \
--verb=EditSelectAll \
--verb=SelectionUnGroup \
--verb=StrokeToPath \
--verb=FileSave \
--verb=FileQuit
```

As you can see, you need pre-installed `sed` and `inkscape`.

Then run it:

```shell
find icons/ -type f | ./strokes-to-paths.sh {}
```

To burn the CPU and also speed up the progress, run it with `parallel`:

```shell
find icons/ -type f | parallel -j4 ./strokes-to-paths.sh {}
```

Though I said `automate` but actually when running the script, you can't do anything else because `inkscape`s GUI will be popped up continuously.

Wow! Your solution worked. There is no error in the console and it also hugely improved the load time. Can you explain me what was the problem here?

Great! The problem is that `https://unpkg.com/feather-icons` is a shortcut that points to `feather.js` which has a relative path to its source map. However, `https://unpkg.com/feather.js.map` doesn't exist. By using the long URL (`https://unpkg.com/feather-icons/dist/feather.min.js`) instead of the shortcut, the relative path to the source map is correct. Also, I gave you the link to the minified version which is probably why it's faster.

I'll update the docs so no one else runs into this issue 👍

@bebosudo You probably haven't build the files, which is why you were not able to see a `/dist` directory.

To get the `/dist` in your repo, run the following commands in the terminal:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/colebemis/feather.git && cd feather
npm install
npm run build
```
You should see the following files in your `/dist` directory & you would be able to see the icons when you open [feather/examples/index.html](https://github.com/colebemis/feather/blob/master/examples/index.html):
```bash
dist
├── feather.js
├── feather.js.map
├── feather.min.js
├── feather.min.js.map
├── icons
└── icons.json
```

Thanks for bringing this to my attention and for writing such a detailed issue description. I have a few questions:
* Is having `width` and `height` attributes on the SVG only an issue when using the icons with the `img` tag? Does it have implications for other usage methods like inline SVG?
* How would you recommend we handle `width` and `height` in the [`toSvg()` method](https://github.com/feathericons/feather#feathericonsnametosvgattrs)? 

I'd love to see a PR of your proposed changes so we can discuss the concrete details.

Well, there are some details to be aware of:

- By removing the `width` and `height` attributes completely, even with the `viewBox` attribute, problems arise with rendering the inline SVG. In my experience, the SVG collapses.
- If the SVG is embedded within an `img` and has only the `viewBox` attribute, then the default size is not consistent. Here is an example Codepen to test in multiple browsers https://codepen.io/iansev/pen/mpeVoR Some browsers set the default size to `{ width: 100%; height: auto; }` **if you have** `viewBox`, other times the default size dates back to the [default sizing of inline elements](https://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/visudet.html#inline-replaced-width) [[Modern Reference](https://drafts.csswg.org/css-sizing-3/#intrinsic-sizes)].

Even though there are these browser issues, I believe that the only reliable solution would be to:
1. Remove the `width` and `height` attributes, and keep only the `viewBox` attribute.
2. Target the Feather icons with CSS to set a default size.

The reason for switching from hard-coding the size attributes on the SVG to using CSS, is that any height or width you set for the SVG with CSS will override the height and width attributes on the `<svg>` (which is standard for any element).

If the solution for the `img` tag + embedded SVG is to have **only** the `viewBox` attribute, and the [W3 spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/single-page.html#struct-SVGElementWidthAttribute) says that

> If the attribute is not specified, the effect is as if a value of '100%' were specified.

then this new structure would be beneficial for multiple reasons:
1. When all browsers iron out the bugs and conform to the spec, all you will have to do is remove the injected CSS function (if you were to create one) and Feather users wouldn't have to change anything. Basically, I'm just saying it would be backward-compatible.
2. You would solve scaling issues for different use cases of Feather, whether being embedded icons, inline, etc.
3. For users that want to use Feather icons offline, you would remove unnecessary code that wouldn't affect them (`width` and `height` attributes).

You can see this in action in [Font Awesome's new release](https://fontawesome.com/how-to-use/svg-with-js) (5) (under "How it Works") where they provide utility classes for their icons to change the size, but as you'll notice, the `width` and `height` is not hard coded in the output SVG.

Something to note, generally speaking, is that when using SVG icons in your code, you usually add some type of styling class on it/nest the icon within a container. This usually includes styling the size. This solves 99% of the problems here already, because their style class is defining the default size. All it needs now is the proper scaling attributes. 😄

Speaking about the `toSvg()` method, there should be no need for `width` and `height`. It could even be considered an anti-pattern, because the users may wonder why the size attributes they set on the SVG are not working when it is actually a class that is wrapped around the SVG that has overridden what they set (for example).

Hope this answers your questions. Would be happy to do a PR if we come to a conclusion!

Run a bash script with the following contents after `npm install` but before webpack (or other build tool). ``` for i in node_modules/vue-feather-icon/components/*; do # egrep -o 'stroke="#000(000){0,1}"' $i # echo 'before'; # egrep -o 'stroke="#[0-9a-zA-Z]*"' $i # sed -i 's/stroke="#000"/stroke="#fff"/' $i sed -i 's/stroke="#[0-9a-zA-Z]*"/stroke="currentColor"/' $i # echo 'after'; egrep -o 'stroke="#[0-9a-zA-Z]*"' $i done ``` You could use `sed -i 's/stroke="#000"/stroke="#fff"/' $i` if you wanted white (`#fff`) instead of black (`#000`). The script sets it to `currentColor` which will take from the HTML. I don't know what side effects you'll have for other uses, such as `` or as a background.

@colebemis 👍 It's all ours now! 😄 
Thanks for creating such great icons and a library that makes it easy to manipulate them. I'm thinking on coding a React component that uses `icons.json` directly. I think is the best way to make a React component for Feather. You may see another PR soon.

Awesome, if you end up working on a React PR, here are my thoughts:

I'd do something like this: [Making SVG icon libraries for React apps](http://nicolasgallagher.com/making-svg-icon-libraries-for-react-apps/)

I'd like to have a separate `react-feather` repo that uses the `feather-icons` npm package. This will allow us to use the `icons` directory to build the React components. With this approach, icons be used like this:
```jsx
import Icon from 'react-feather'

<Icon name="circle" />
```

or

```jsx
import IconCircle from 'react-feather/circle'

<IconCircle />
```

Since there is already a [`react-feather`](https://github.com/carmelopullara/react-feather) repo, it probably makes more sense to update that repo to use the approach outlined in the article above. I'd like to transfer that repo into the [feathericons](https://github.com/feathericons) organization if @carmelopullara is on board.

Hrm. I would say out-of-context it's definitely not clear. In-context, maybe? It's unfortunate that most languages don't have a recognizable mark, and it gets even harder if you're trying to represent it in a minimalist, less-detailed style. A language like Ruby is highly-recognizable—a Ruby as a mark could be detailed or simple and people will still know it's a Ruby. Even non-Rubyists will know it. But with Node.js, I don't think even some Nodists (?) would recognize the green octagon “o”. I use Node pretty regularly and I didn't know that was one of the marks. Another alternative might be nested octagons? It might look more like an “o” that way, or perhaps call to mind the “e”? AWS uses a similar shape to represent their SDKs in different languages. Rather than try to make a mark for each one they use color to differentiate the different languages, but that wouldn't work here.

Thanks for bringing this up, @KOLANICH. I agree that `feather.replace()` is not the best option for production code as it can create an undesirable flash effect when the page loads (https://github.com/feathericons/feather/issues/441). Currently, my preferred way to use Feather is with `feather.icons[<icon-name>].toSvg()` inside a server-side rendered or statically generated site using something like Next.js or Gatsby. That said, I think `feather.replace()` has it's place for prototyping as it allows people to get started using Feather quickly [in the browser](https://codepen.io/pen?template=WOJZdM). I think maybe adding a disclaimer in the README about the drawbacks of `feather.replace()` would be sufficient. What do you think?

If you manage to find an automated way to build a font out of images, I would recommend not relying on external repos, but adding fonts directly to Github releases in this repo. It is possible to configure Travis to automatically build the font and automatically attach it to the release — this is completely transparent and doesn't require project maintainers to do anything extra once the process is properly set up.

I configured this for Emojione a while ago, here's how to do it: https://github.com/emojione/emojione-assets/pull/30

What is needed is for someone to create a Docker image that can build Feather font, this image will be used by the Travis build. In the link above the Docker image is called `maximbaz/emojione-fonts-build`, and its code is hosted here: https://github.com/maximbaz/docker-emojione-fonts-build

Okay, here's my first stab at some guidelines. I'll continue to update this comment as I have time, then move it into a markdown file when I feel like it's mostly complete.

---

## Constraints
These are strict constraints of the system and cannot be broken.

- Every icon fits in a 24x24 canvas.
- Every line and shape has a 2px center-aligned stroke with round joins and round caps.
- No fills.

## Guidelines
These are general guidelines that help create consistency but can be broken on a case-by-case basis.

**90° corners should have a 2px radius:**

![2019-01-17 at 14 22](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4608155/51352731-5912ce80-1a63-11e9-8dce-d724fba860df.png)

**Icons should have a 1px empty “safe zone” on the edges of the canvas:**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4608155/51352384-42b84300-1a62-11e9-91ee-7d14016283eb.png)

**Distinct elements of an icon should be seperated by at least 2px of empty space:**

![2019-01-17 at 14 20](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4608155/51352620-03d6bd00-1a63-11e9-98d5-6dd534cbbecf.png)

**Icons should have similar "optical volumes:"**

| Good | Bad |
| --- | --- |
| ![2019-01-17 at 14 24](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4608155/51352857-b60e8480-1a63-11e9-8d84-990e4f4f960d.png) | ![2019-01-17 at 14 25](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4608155/51352876-c9b9eb00-1a63-11e9-958b-01f1f63456a1.png) |

See the "Grid and Optical Volume" section of [Nucleo's Icon Guidelines](https://blog.nucleoapp.com/nucleo-icon-guidelines-introduction-70092f8b4697).

## Project Setup

```shell
# Clone the repo
git clone https://github.com/feathericons/feather.git
cd feather

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Run `all` script to make sure everything is set up properly
npm run all

# If the `all` script completes successfully, you're good to go!
```

## Adding an Icon

1. Export the icon as an SVG from Figma/Illustrator/etc.
1. Create a new local branch
1. Place the SVG in the [`icons` directory](https://github.com/feathericons/feather/tree/master/icons)
1. Run `npm run build`
1. Commit the SVG file
1. Open a pull request

After messing around with this for a while, I believe this is the best option for the npm logo: ![npm logo good](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9214195/55371762-63befa80-54cd-11e9-85dc-90130befc425.png) I tried it with varying line widths, to account for the different styles they have used (even line thickness and gap thickness vs thicker gap) and have found that they mostly use even widths in their newer logos. I also tested the difference between 2px rounded corners versus slightly rounded corners: and overall the design feels more consistent with the original logo when using the less rounded corners. it also visually translates better in icon size in my opinion. ![npm logo good small](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9214195/55372141-b0ef9c00-54ce-11e9-98db-9528a8da8e4f.png) vs ![npm bad](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9214195/55372234-0035cc80-54cf-11e9-80f6-38a7a94439a9.png) I know this does not follow the standard 2px border radius that 90 degree angles but given that its a logo and many of the logos in this package break that rule I figure it might be ok. Besides that, it follows the 2px gap and stroke rules along with the consistent optical volume. Anyway, these are just my thoughts! I have attached my Figma file with all of my work along with a built version of the SVG.
